Group Details.Description: APT32is a suspected Vietnam-based threat group that has been active since at least 2014. The group has targeted multiple private sector industries as well as foreign governments, dissidents, and journalists with a strong focus on Southeast Asian countries like Vietnam, the Philippines, Laos, and Cambodia. They have extensively used strategic web compromises to compromise victims.[1][2][3]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Account Discovery: Local Account
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 enumerated administrative users using the commands net localgroup administrators.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Acquire Infrastructure: Domains
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has set up and operated websites to gather information and deliver malware.[9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Acquire Infrastructure: Web Services
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has set up Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive to host malicious downloads.[9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used JavaScript that communicates over HTTP or HTTPS to attacker controlled domains to download additional frameworks. The group has also used downloaded encrypted payloads over HTTP.[2][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Application Layer Protocol: Mail Protocols
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used email for C2 via an Office macro.[4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Archive Collected Data
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor has used LZMA compression and RC4 encryption before exfiltration.[5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 established persistence using Registry Run keys, both to execute PowerShell and VBS scripts as well as to execute their backdoor directly.[4][8][5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used COM scriptlets to download Cobalt Strike beacons.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: PowerShell
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used PowerShell-based tools, PowerShell one-liners, and shellcode loaders for execution.[1][4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Windows Command Shell
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used cmd.exe for execution.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Visual Basic
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used macros, COM scriptlets, and VBS scripts.[4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: JavaScript
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used JavaScript for drive-by downloads and C2 communications.[8][9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 modified Windows Services to ensure PowerShell scripts were loaded on the system. APT32 also creates a Windows service to establish persistence.[3][8][5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.[3][9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Establish Accounts: Social Media Accounts
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has set up Facebook pages in tandem with fake websites.[9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor can exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.[5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor has exfiltrated data using the already opened channel with its C&C server.[5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used RTF document that includes an exploit to execute malicious code. (CVE-2017-11882)[5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.[1]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor possesses the capability to list files and directories on a machine. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2019/03/20/fake-or-fake-keeping-up-with-oceanlotus-decoys/

Tactics and Techniques.Name: File and Directory Permissions Modification: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's macOS backdoor changes the permission of the file it wants to execute to 755.[10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Gather Victim Identity Information
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has conducted targeted surveillance against activists and bloggers.[6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Email Addresses
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has collected e-mail addresses for activists and bloggers in order to target them with spyware.[6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Hide Artifacts: Hidden Files and Directories
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's macOS backdoor hides the clientID file via a chflags function.[10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Hide Artifacts: Hidden Window
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal PowerShell windows. https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2017/05/cyber-espionage-apt32.html https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/3354902/Cybereason%20Labs%20Analysis%20Operation%20Cobalt%20Kitty.pdf

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Hide Artifacts: NTFS File Attributes
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used NTFS alternate data streams to hide their payloads.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Side-Loading
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 ran legitimately-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which load a malicious DLL. The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable (AcroTranscoder).[4][8][5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has cleared select event log entries.[1]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Indicator Removal: File Deletion
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's macOS backdoor can receive a "delete" command.[10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Indicator Removal: Timestomp
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used scheduled task raw XML with a backdated timestamp of June 2, 2016. The group has also set the creation time of the files dropped by the second stage of the exploit to match the creation time of kernel32.dll. Additionally, APT32 has used a random value to modify the timestamp of the file storing the clientID.[1][5][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has added JavaScript to victim websites to download additional frameworks that profile and compromise website visitors.[2]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Input Capture: Keylogging
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has abused the PasswordChangeNotify to monitor for and capture account password changes.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Lateral Tool Transfer
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has deployed tools after moving laterally using administrative accounts.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Masquerading
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has disguised a Cobalt Strike beacon as a Flash Installer.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Rename System Utilities
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has moved and renamed pubprn.vbs to a .txt file to avoid detection.[11]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Masquerade Task or Service
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used hidden or non-printing characters to help masquerade service names, such as appending a Unicode no-break space character to a legitimate service name. APT32 has also impersonated the legitimate Flash installer file name "install_flashplayer.exe".[1]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has renamed a NetCat binary to kb-10233.exe to masquerade as a Windows update. APT32 has also renamed a Cobalt Strike beacon payload to install_flashplayers.exe. [8][9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Modify Registry
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor has modified the Windows Registry to store the backdoor's configuration. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2019/03/20/fake-or-fake-keeping-up-with-oceanlotus-decoys/

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Network Service Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 performed network scanning on the network to search for open ports, services, OS finger-printing, and other vulnerabilities.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Network Share Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used the net view command to show all shares available, including the administrative shares such as C$ and ADMIN$.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Non-Standard Port
Tactics and Techniques.Use: An APT32 backdoor can use HTTP over a non-standard TCP port (e.g 14146) which is specified in the backdoor configuration.[5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Binary Padding
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 includes garbage code to mislead anti-malware software and researchers.[3][5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used the Invoke-Obfuscation framework to obfuscate their PowerShell.[1][12][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Fileless Storage
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor has stored its configuration in a registry key.[5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Encrypted/Encoded File
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has performed code obfuscation, including encoding payloads using Base64 and using a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC). APT32 also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.[1][12][3][4][8][5][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Obtain Capabilities: Tool
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz and Cobalt Strike, and a variety of other open-source tools from GitHub.[1][4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Office Application Startup
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 have replaced Microsoft Outlook's VbaProject.OTM file to install a backdoor macro for persistence.[4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: OS Credential Dumping
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used GetPassword_x64 to harvest credentials.[4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: LSASS Memory
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used Mimikatz and customized versions of Windows Credential Dumper to harvest credentials.[4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet.[3][4][8][5][13][6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Phishing: Spearphishing Link
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.[3][4][13][9][6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Phishing for Information: Spearphishing Link
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used malicious links to direct users to web pages designed to harvest credentials.[9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Process Injection
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 malware has injected a Cobalt Strike beacon into Rundll32.exe.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Query Registry
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor can query the Windows Registry to gather system information. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2019/03/20/fake-or-fake-keeping-up-with-oceanlotus-decoys/

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used Net to use Windows' hidden network shares to copy their tools to remote machines for execution.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Remote System Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has enumerated DC servers using the command net group "Domain Controllers" /domain. The group has also used the ping command.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Scheduled Task/Job: Scheduled Task
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used scheduled tasks to persist on victim systems.[1][4][8][5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Server Software Component: Web Shell
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used Web shells to maintain access to victim websites.[2]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Software Deployment Tools
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 compromised McAfee ePO to move laterally by distributing malware as a software deployment task.[1]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Stage Capabilities: Upload Malware
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has hosted malicious payloads in Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive for use during targeting.[9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Stage Capabilities: Drive-by Target
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has stood up websites containing numerous articles and content scraped from the Internet to make them appear legitimate, but some of these pages include malicious JavaScript to profile the potential victim or infect them via a fake software update.[9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Binary Proxy Execution: Mshta
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used mshta.exe for code execution.[4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Binary Proxy Execution: Regsvr32
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 created a Scheduled Task/Job that used regsvr32.exe to execute a COM scriptlet that dynamically downloaded a backdoor and injected it into memory. The group has also used regsvr32 to run their backdoor.[5][1][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Binary Proxy Execution: Rundll32
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 malware has used rundll32.exe to execute an initial infection process.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Information Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has collected the OS version and computer name from victims. One of the group's backdoors can also query the Windows Registry to gather system information, and another macOS backdoor performs a fingerprint of the machine on its first connection to the C&C server. APT32 executed shellcode to identify the name of the infected host.[3][5][10][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used the ipconfig /all command to gather the IP address from the system.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used the netstat -anpo tcp command to display TCP connections on the victim's machine.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 collected the victim's username and executed the whoami command on the victim's machine. APT32 executed shellcode to collect the username on the victim's machine. [13][3][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Script Proxy Execution: PubPrn
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used PubPrn.vbs within execution scripts to execute malware, possibly bypassing defenses.[14]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Services: Service Execution
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32's backdoor has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2019/03/20/fake-or-fake-keeping-up-with-oceanlotus-decoys/

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Registry
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used Outlook Credential Dumper to harvest credentials stored in Windows registry.[4][8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used pass the hash for lateral movement.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Ticket
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 successfully gained remote access by using pass the ticket.[8]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: User Execution: Malicious Link
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has lured targets to download a Cobalt Strike beacon by including a malicious link within spearphishing emails.[8][9][6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: User Execution: Malicious File
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has attempted to lure users to execute a malicious dropper delivered via a spearphishing attachment.[3][4][5][13][6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Valid Accounts: Local Accounts
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used legitimate local admin account credentials.[1]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Web Service
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 has used Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive to host malicious downloads.[9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Tactics and Techniques.Use: APT32 used WMI to deploy their tools on remote machines and to gather information about the Outlook process.[8]

Tools.Techniques: Remote System Discovery, System Network Configuration Discovery
